Severity classification: Mild to moderate, as symptoms are recent and localized without signs of significant globe rupture or visual impairment. Urgency level: Routine care, unless vision changes or worsening symptoms occur. Differential considerations still requiring monitoring: Possible underlying bleeding diatheses related to systemic disease, or other orbital/ocular trauma complications.  STEP 2 - EVIDENCE-BASED TREATMENT SELECTION: First-line treatment per guidelines: Observation for subconjunctival hemorrhage, using artificial tears for comfort; avoid unnecessary medications. Supporting evidence: Most subconjunctival hemorrhages resolve spontaneously within 2 weeks; trauma management is conservative. Patient-specific considerations: Underlying lymphoma may affect bleeding or immune response; no anticoagulation unless indicated. Contraindications or cautions: Avoid NSAIDs if bleeding risk increased due to systemic condition; monitor for signs of increasing hemorrhage or eye discomfort.  STEP 3 - PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: Primary medication choice: Artificial tears or lubricating eye drops as needed for comfort, no systemic medications typically required. Rationale for selection: Provides symptomatic relief without bleeding risk. Expected timeline for improvement: Symptoms typically resolve in 1-2 weeks. Key side effects to monitor: Minimal; ensure no signs of worsening hemorrhage or infection. Alternative medications if first-line fails: None generally needed; if irritation persists, consider preservative-free artificial tears.  STEP 4 - NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: Primary non-drug interventions: Avoid eye rubbing, strenuous activity, or trauma; use protective eyewear if needed. Patient education priorities: Inform patient about the benign nature of subconjunctival hemorrhage, expected healing time, and signs of complications. Lifestyle modifications: Rest and avoid activities that increase ocular or systemic bleeding risk. Behavioral interventions: Stress cautious eye handling and adherence to systemic treatment plans for lymphoma.  STEP 5 - MONITORING & FOLLOW-UP STRATEGY: Follow-up timeline: Re-evaluate in 1-2 weeks or sooner if worsening symptoms develop. Monitoring parameters: Symptom progression, visual acuity, appearance of eye, and systemic signs. Red flag symptoms: Sudden vision loss, increasing pain, enlarging hemorrhage, or signs of orbital compartment syndrome. Treatment response assessment: Resolution of redness and swelling, stability or improvement in symptoms.  STEP 6 - PATIENT COMMUNICATION STRATEGY: Communication approach: Use clear, straightforward language, avoiding medical jargon, and check understanding by asking questions. Addressing patient concerns: Reassure about the benign nature of trauma-related hemorrhage and reassure that systemic condition is monitored separately. Adherence strategies: Provide written instructions and schedules for follow-up; encourage questions. Family involvement: If appropriate, inform family members about eye care and need for follow-up, respecting patient privacy.  STEP 7 - COORDINATION & REFERRALS: Specialist referrals needed: Ophthalmology consult if no improvement in 2 weeks or if complications arise; oncologist for ongoing systemic management of lymphoma. Other healthcare team members: Primary care provider to coordinate systemic health, or hematology/oncology as indicated. Community resources: Provide educational materials on eye trauma and lymphoma management support groups. Insurance/cost considerations: Confirm coverage for specialist visits; provide assistance with appointment scheduling if needed.
